class="section firstReview">      <div id="review_38425392" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/38425392" />    <a title="Jason Koivu" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1742824-jason-koivu"><img alt="Jason Koivu" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1464843865p2/1742824.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/38425392?book_show_action=false">Jul 21, 2015</a>      <a title="Jason Koivu" class="user" name="Jason Koivu" href="/user/show/1742824-jason-koivu">Jason Koivu</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1742824-jason-koivu?shelf=fiction">fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1742824-jason-koivu?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer38425392" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14491367009029908085">If the "shit got real" in the last book, well, in this fourth book shit got unreal.<br /><br /><i>Goblet of Fire</i> took the series forward and yet in tone it felt like a regression to the first two books. Certainly it is darker and slightly more mature in subject matter. However, there's a lingering "freshman" feel which I blame on the inclusion of the Tri Wizard Tournament. It seemed out of place at this point in the story. <br /><br />I have no problem with the idea that the wizarding establishment didn't believe (or want</span>  <span id="freeText14491367009029908085" style="display:none">If the "shit got real" in the last book, well, in this fourth book shit got unreal.<br /><br /><i>Goblet of Fire</i> took the series forward and yet in tone it felt like a regression to the first two books. Certainly it is darker and slightly more mature in subject matter. However, there's a lingering "freshman" feel which I blame on the inclusion of the Tri Wizard Tournament. It seemed out of place at this point in the story. <br /><br />I have no problem with the idea that the wizarding establishment didn't believe (or want to believe) that Voldemort was back and ergo they would naturally carry on with their lives, as would the students, so the big sporting event is not precisely my issue. It's the amount of time spent on the event I'm taking to task. As readers, we know the ultimate evil has come again, so it's hard to suspend our dread and enjoy the fun and games of the tournament, or at least it was hard for me. <br /><br />Others I've spoke to don't seem to mind the "fun and games" aspect of this book. However, to me it seemed like Rowling hadn't given the storyline maturation its due. Was this a lack of skill on her part? Mishandling of story pacing is just as important as plot, realistic characters, appropriate dialogue and knowing how to put one word after another in the correct order. <br /><br />Perhaps the "let them eat cake" atmosphere of tragedy veiled is <i>just</i> what was called for. Time and again, history proves this scenario holds true for some. I wasn't buying it though.<br /><br /><b>Rating: 3.5</b> - <i>Goblet...</i> gets perhaps a higher rating from me than you'd think after reading that complainypants review, but the fact is the book is still entertaining, and at this point I was so very wrapped up in the series that Rowling could've taken a dump, published it and I would've given it at least two stars. </span>  <a data-text-id="14491367009029908085" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1169592304" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1169592304" />    <a title="Kate U+2661" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/15154637-kate"><img alt="Kate U+2661" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1450402290p2/15154637.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1169592304?book_show_action=false">Sep 27, 2015</a>      <a title="Kate U+2661" class="user" name="Kate U+2661" href="/user/show/15154637-kate">Kate U+2661</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408810576" href="/book/show/7979788-harry-potter-and-the-goblet-of-fire">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15154637-kate?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15154637-kate?shelf=2015-read">2015-read</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1169592304" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1539918887205881203"><b>BLOG POST REVIEW:</b><br /><a target="_blank" href="https://thebookgram.wordpress.com/2015/08/16/harry-potter-and-the-goblet-of-fire-review/" rel="nofollow">https://thebookgram.wordpress.com/201...</a><br /><br /><i>Actual Rating: 4.5/5 stars</i><br />Ah, J.K. Rowling truly is a genius! The way this book is moulded together is a true art and masterpiece. It continues to baffle me how one could come up with such an incredible story like this, simply from their own mind.<br /><br />In this novel, we begin to see the start of Ron and HermioneU+2019s future relationship, and it was so cute to read about RonU+2019s obvious jealousy.<br /><br />This book really set up the eerie tone for the next book</span>  <span id="freeText1539918887205881203" style="display:none"><b>BLOG POST REVIEW:</b><br /><a target="_blank" href="https://thebookgram.wordpress.com/2015/08/16/harry-potter-and-the-goblet-of-fire-review/" rel="nofollow">https://thebookgram.wordpress.com/201...</a><br /><br /><i>Actual Rating: 4.5/5 stars</i><br />Ah, J.K. Rowling truly is a genius! The way this book is moulded together is a true art and masterpiece. It continues to baffle me how one could come up with such an incredible story like this, simply from their own mind.<br /><br />In this novel, we begin to see the start of Ron and HermioneU+2019s future relationship, and it was so cute to read about RonU+2019s obvious jealousy.<br /><br />This book really set up the eerie tone for the next books, and I canU+2019t wait to see how dark the story ends up going, as I know it definitely gets a-lot darker in terms of the movies.<br /><br />I loved Dumbledore and Sirius in this, and HermioneU+2019s bad-assery really started to kick off towards the end! I canU+2019t wait to see how that progresses. The words Dumbledore says just shows how wise he is, and I love it!<br /><br />J.K. RowlingU+2019s use of the Dementors is an incredible link to what theyU+2019re supposed to represent, which is depression. IU+2019ll share with you a line that made me appreciate Ms. RowlingU+2019s brain on this even more than I previously did:<br /><br />U+201CMost go mad in there, and plenty stop eating in the end. They lose the will to live. You could always tell when a death was coming, because the Dementors could sense it, they got excited.U+201D<br /><br />There certainly are some incredible quotes and passages throughout this novel, and I bow down to you, J.K. Rowling. IU+2019m so excited to continue to read how Harry and his friends grow and mature, as the tone of the book does also.</span>  <a data-text-id="1539918887205881203" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1169592304">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1169592304" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1169592304&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/6.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1169592304'><a id="like_count_review_1169592304" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1169592304?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">49 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1169592304" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1169592304" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=49&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1169592304&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1169592304" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1169592304, true, &#39;&#39;); Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5944522-sanaa?shelf=read-books-i-own">read-books-i-own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1372961998" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5174890940089324846">Bought this book when I was abroad in Paris the first time!</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1372961998">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1372961998" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." id='like_container_review_1372961998'><a id="like_count_review_1372961998" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1372961998?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">43 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1372961998" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1372961998" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1372961998" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1372961998, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">comment</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1372961998?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1372961998' style='display: '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1471598053" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1471598053" />    <a title="Councillor" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/40792319-councillor"><img alt="Councillor" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1437208837p2/40792319.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1471598053?book_show_action=false">Jul 13, 2016</a>      <a title="Councillor" class="user" name="Councillor" href="/user/show/40792319-councillor">Councillor</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=21st-century">21st-century</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=uk-ireland">uk-ireland</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=action-adventure">action-adventure</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=rated-4-and-a-half-stars">rated-4-and-a-half-stars</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=to-read-2016-priority">to-read-2016-priority</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=read-2016">read-2016</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=coming-of-age">coming-of-age</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=dragons">dragons</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=library">library</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=expectations-were-high">expectations-were-high</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=friendship">friendship</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=will-be-a-classic-in-100-years">will-be-a-classic-in-100-years</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=the-4th-book-in-a-series">the-4th-book-in-a-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40792319-councillor?shelf=school-setting">school-setting</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1471598053" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12791500100239759070">Believe it or not - yes, I finally read the fourth book in the Harry Potter series, a book which made me anticipate the next three installments in the series even more eagerly. A Harry Potter book is no book you simply <i>read</i>; it is a book you are allowed to <i>live in</i>. I don't know any fantasy world which feels as realistic as this one. While the first three books were comparatively short, this one was - so far - the longest with 766 pages. <i>766 pages?</i> It felt like 300, considering my pace while rush</span>  <span id="freeText12791500100239759070" style="display:none">Believe it or not - yes, I finally read the fourth book in the Harry Potter series, a book which made me anticipate the next three installments in the series even more eagerly. A Harry Potter book is no book you simply <i>read</i>; it is a book you are allowed to <i>live in</i>. I don't know any fantasy world which feels as realistic as this one. While the first three books were comparatively short, this one was - so far - the longest with 766 pages. <i>766 pages?</i> It felt like 300, considering my pace while rushing through this book.<br><u>Please choose wisely before reading this review. There are no specific spoilers, but in case you haven't read the first four books in the series, you might want to turn away from this review.</u><br><br>Until now, <i>The Goblet of Fire</i> was the Harry Potter book I enjoyed most because it managed to find the perfect point of balance between the dark, gloomy and complex plot elements surrounding the return of Vol ... sorry, <i>You Know Who</i>, and the light-hearted, funny scenes which managed to conjure a smile on my face whenever another one of those appeared during the course of the book. Still I couldn't bring myself to rate this with five stars, as there were quite a few things which bothered me. (And yes, I know that I am getting myself in severe danger right now with saying this. I will better take to my heels and run as fast as I can after posting this review.)<br><br>First of all, in case you have not already realized this during <i>The Prisoner of Azkaban</i>, the Harry Potter series is far away from being a children's book series anymore. Especially in the beginning and the ending, horror elements outweigh everything else, crying at the reader, <i>"This is no children's book you are reading anymore!"</i> Well, then why does J.K. Rowling still constantly fall back to the habit of using childish language? A short search of the story brought up nearly 1,400 exclamation marks. And everytime I stumbled upon yet another one, the only thing I could think of was this picture ...<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1459954023i/18678390._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>But well, by now, I have developed a soft spot for Harry Potter books, and sometimes childish writing style is not <i>that bad</i>, just ... <i>kind of annoying</i>. However, quite a few other things bothered me while reading this book, and I will now try to go through them as fast as possible. After all, I have learned one thing about discussions in my school time which still stays with me - list the arguments your reader should forget about first, then he will be even more convinced by the positive arguments you will list afterwards.<br><br>U+25BA Rita Skeeter. I am sure just dropping her name makes a lot of fans of the series want her to meet a Dementor. However, the way she appeared made me think of her as a pure caricature, causing nothing but trouble, without being even the slightest bit complex, simply annoying and not the least obstacle to write as a character because of her one-dimensional appearance. I would have loved to see some more insight into her character, but sadly ... J.K. Rowling decided to just present us with a caricature.<br>U+25BA How could someone as dumb as Fudge be Minister for Magic? (That's no true criticism. After all, just look at some of our real world's politicians. And yet ... can someone please lock up Fudge right beside Rita?)<br>U+25BA The next tournament should include a <i>World Cup of Perfection</i>. Dumbledore would almost certainly win.<br>U+25BA Why isn't Hermione more prominent? Certain parts of the books made me wish for her character to have a more major role.<br><br>Now that the reasons for my 4-star-rating are out of the way, here comes what I loved about the book:<br><br>U+25BA DOBBY. I know there are quite a few people who didn't like his uncommon behavior, but I fell in love with him. He is probably the cutest and most adorable character of the entire series, and his actions are always based on good-hearted motivations. Go, Dobby!<br>U+25BA <i>Socks that scream when they stink?</i> Definitely my favorite moment of the book.<br>U+25BA DRAGONS!<br>U+25BA There are new characters, there are old characters, but they all have a certain depth. (No, Rita, I am not speaking of you.) I especially loved how the dynamics between Ron, Hermione and Harry were explored by throwing some obstacles for their friendships into the game. And <a href="http://www.thegloss.com/2011/07/13/culture/why-harry-potter-should-really-be-all-about-hermione-granger/" rel="nofollow">this article</a> perfectly highlights why Hermione should have a more prominent role in the books.<br>U+25BA The Triwizard Tournament was pure awesomeness. I loved every part of it, and I am not ashamed to admit it.<br>U+25BA (Almost) nothing is predictable in this series. I was <b>so</b> sure to find out <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Bagman <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> is the true culprit, but ... J.K. Rowling took my prediction and shred it to pieces. (I only wish that my intention to predict things will not continue to be destroyed by spoilers people seem to carelessly leave all over the internet. I will leave a huge thank you right here to the person who spoiled all the upcoming deaths in the next three books to me ... in a review for the second Harry Potter book. Thank you.)<br>U+25BA There are actually signs of romance! Now let's hope there will be some more developments on the romantic level of these books, because even though I hate when romantic entanglements are thrown into the story just to make sure the reader roots for the oh-so perfect protagonists, these books need some romance. Harry, Ron and Hermione are teenagers now, and I totally want to see them discovering that children aren't born just because two people care about each other.<br>U+25BA I want more of Cho Chang. Seriously.<br>U+25BA Hagrid might not be as cute as Dobby, but he is certainly just as adorable.<br>U+25BA This has the best world-building <i>ever</i>. I never liked the fantasy genre; there was even a time which saw me absolutely and whole-heartedly <i>loathing</i> it.<br>And then I read Harry Potter.<br><br><b>Two final thoughts on this book:</b><br><br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<b>An athlete:</b> What was the most important moment in the history of sports?<br><b>Me:</b> Viktor Krum caught the snitch, but Ireland won. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br>And finally ...<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1459956203i/18678922._SY540_.jpg" width="240" height="600" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br><b>My reviews in the Harry Potter series:</b><br><br>1) <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone</a>: <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1316706192?book_show_action=false">Go to review</a><br>2) <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Harry_Potter___2_" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</a>: <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1469645452?book_show_action=false">Go to review</a><br>3) <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/5.Harry_Potter_and_the_Prisoner_of_Azkaban__Harry_Potter___3_" title="Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (Harry Potter, #3) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban</a>: <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1471598035?book_show_action=false">Go to review</a><br><br><br>Order of the Phoenix, here I come.</["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="12791500100239759070" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1471598053">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1471598053" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1471598053&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/6.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1471598053'><a id="like_count_review_1471598053" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1471598053?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">64 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1471598053" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1471598053" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=64&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=1471598053&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_1471598053" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 1471598053, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">31 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1471598053?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1471598053' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1471598053/comments?reverse=true">View all 31 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div><div id="comment_156923566" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Adita U+2728The Slumbering InsomniacU+2728" href="/user/show/37265034-adita-the-slumbering-insomniac"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467396795p1/37265034.jpg" alt="37265034" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/37265034-adita-the-slumbering-insomniac">Adita U+2728The Slumbering InsomniacU+2728</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer2179527311481123843">Reflecting Medini's thoughts on Cho Chang. "You want more of her." Seriously?? Right from the start, I hated her for hogging Harry's attention which</span>  <span id="freeText2179527311481123843" style="display:none">Reflecting Medini's thoughts on Cho Chang. "You want more of her." Seriously?? Right from the start, I hated her for hogging Harry's attention which rightfully belongs to Ginny! :)</span>  <a data-text-id="2179527311481123843" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Sep 17, 2016 01:37AM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div><div id="comment_157043155" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Councillor" href="/user/show/40792319-councillor"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1437208837p1/40792319.jpg" alt="40792319" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/40792319-councillor">Councillor</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer143999261171952322">Thank you, Adita! :))<br />And yes, I did like Cho a lot until we got to a certain point. Now it's actually indeed Ginny I am rooting for to some extent.</span>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Sep 20, 2016 01:26AM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1471598053' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1471598053, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_262535509" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/262535509" />    <a title="Jay Kristoff" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4901961-jay-kristoff"><img alt="Jay Kristoff" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1296449592p2/4901961.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/262535509?book_show_action=false">Jan 15, 2012</a>      <a title="Jay Kristoff" class="user" name="Jay Kristoff" href="/user/show/4901961-jay-kristoff">Jay Kristoff</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer262535509" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2524082424108099197">This was the book that broke me from the HP series. My bride insists they got better, but she also married me, so her taste is... suspect.<br /><br />I loved Prisoner of Azkaban. Great struggle, clever time-travel story (very hard to do) and our first real glimpses of the dark places where this series would head. I liked that shift, I really did. So what broke me?<br /><br />Firstly, the plot holes. Well, more accurately, one plot hole, but it was a frackin' doozy. You know the opening scene in Star Wars where the came</span>  <span id="freeText2524082424108099197" style="display:none">This was the book that broke me from the HP series. My bride insists they got better, but she also married me, so her taste is... suspect.<br /><br />I loved Prisoner of Azkaban. Great struggle, clever time-travel story (very hard to do) and our first real glimpses of the dark places where this series would head. I liked that shift, I really did. So what broke me?<br /><br />Firstly, the plot holes. Well, more accurately, one plot hole, but it was a frackin' doozy. You know the opening scene in Star Wars where the camera is beneath the belly of the Star Destroyer and the shot just goes on and on for about ten frackin' minutes and you can practically hear George Lucas yelling "That's right, Star Destroyers are REALLY BIG, bitches!"? Well, this was a Star Destroyer sized plot hole. <br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ Rowling goes to some length spelling out that portkeys can be anything. A cup. A book. A fluffy bunny. She also establishes that you can't teleport in and out of Hogwarts, because it's warded. Fair enough. BUT, Harry and his chums have often left the grounds of HG's, to go and drink 'butterbeer' or buy living chocolate frogs or snog in alleyways or whatever. The precedent has been set that they can and do leave the school grounds. FFS, Harry lived outside of Hogwarts for YEARS (and yeah Uncle Owen and Aunt Beru's [or whatever] place was magicked so folks couldn't find him, but how did he get back and forth to it, eh? A TRAIN.)<br /><br />SO, you are an evil overlord trying to take over the world. You need Harry's blood to get your body back. You have an agent WITHIN Hogwarts, despite all these magical defenses, disguised as a teacher that Harry implicitly trusts.<br /><br />Do you:<br /><br />a) Set in place an elaborate ruse, framed around this enormous tri-wizard tournament, which (presumably) is under scrutiny by the most powerful wizards in the world and the ministry of magic, in which you manipulate events so that Harry not only enters the tournament (despite rules that expressly say that he's not old enough) but wins it, touches the tri-wizard cup, which, despite all these defenses and wizard-y scrutiny and security, you've managed to turn into a frackin' portkey (yes, you're that good) so that he gets teleported away from the tourney grounds into your evil clutches and hey, you bleed that bitch.<br /><br />b) Have your agent (who Harry implicitly trusts) say "hey Potter, what's say we head down to the pub for a mug of butterbeer and I'll tell you some stuff about your dad/mum/long lost twin?" use all your evil-wizardyness to change a mug of butterbeer into a portkey, and save everyone around 400 pages of this book.<br /><br />Sorry, but I didn't buy it. I've read many fan arguments explaining why the tri-wizard tournament and everything around it wasn't window-dressing on an overly complicated plan, the fruits of which could have very easily been borne by a far less convoluted and complex Evil Scheme(tm) which, granted, probably wouldn't have made a very interesting book, but YOUR WAREZ, I AM NOT BUYING THEM. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />But second, and more importantly, it was in GoF that I realized that Harry was going to win. That he was just awesome, and no matter what rules were set in place (you're too young to enter the tournament/you're ten years old, why on earth would we put you in the CLUTCH position on our Quidditch team/you wear glasses, the ladiez don't dig dudes in glasses) he would triumph. Rowling LOVED Harry. She loved all the Harry gang. Too much. And it became painfully obvious that these kids were going to win, without a single fatality/crippling sacrifice/crushing loss. That in the end, Voldemort would be beaten, and Harry would marry Ginny, and Ron would marry Hermione and everyone would live happily ever after and make lots of adorable wizard babies.<br /><br />This was the book Harry ceased being a character and became a caricature. A SUPERHERO. Superheros bore me. I want torment. I want LOSS. I want my heroes to pay a TANGIBLE and TERRIBLE price for their victories. And no, killing tertiary characters doesn't count. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Digory? The Weasley twin? Even Dumbledore (yeah I know he dies, I got spoiled) is disposable.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />I need to believe my heroes could fail. I know they probably won't. I know the good guys will eventually win. But I need to be afraid for them. I need to be scanning the faces of the MAIN characters and wondering "which one of you will be dead/emotionally crippled/hideously disfigured before the final act is over?" And I never believed for a second that Rowling would harm a hair on their heady-head-heads.<br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[And, turns out, she didn't. :P <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />(shrugs)</span>  <a data-text-id="2524082424108099197" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review262535509">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link262535509" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=262535509&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/6.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_262535509'><a id="like_count_review_262535509" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/262535509?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">42 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_262535509" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_262535509" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=42&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=262535509&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_262535509" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 262535509, true, &#39;&#39;); style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/4670884-katelyn">Katelyn</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer8548340662488640538">While Harry himself doesn't get hurt, his choices effect his friends (even their lives) and I'd say emotionally Harry suffers a lot from what he's</span>  <span id="freeText8548340662488640538" style="display:none">While Harry himself doesn't get hurt, his choices effect his </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_854590711" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/854590711" />    <a title="Vane J." class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/19590155-vane-j"><img alt="Vane J." src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1468102148p2/19590155.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/854590711?book_show_action=false">Jan 17, 2016</a>      <a title="Vane J." class="user" name="Vane J." href="/user/show/19590155-vane-j">Vane J.</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=favourites">favourites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=amazing-characters">amazing-characters</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=2012">2012</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=speshul-snowflake">speshul-snowflake</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=all-the-feels">all-the-feels</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer854590711" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5815684212622852246"><b>THIS IS THE BEST <i>HARRY POTTER</i> BOOK OF ALL.</b><br><br>And the darkest, most complex, heart-wrenching, exciting, funniest of them all so far. It is also the book in which my reaction after finishing changes from:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1424084444ra/13714080.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>... to:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1452814431ra/17747633.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>All that in a matter of a hundred pages.<br><br>For all of you people who have not read these books, I need to tell you one thing: <b>This damned series has every freaking thing you can think about, even horror.</b><br><br>Yes, my friends, there's horror of the kind that makes you stare at the book with eyes very wi</span>  <span id="freeText5815684212622852246" style="display:none"><b>THIS IS THE BEST <i>HARRY POTTER</i> BOOK OF ALL.</b><br><br>And the darkest, most complex, heart-wrenching, exciting, funniest of them all so far. It is also the book in which my reaction after finishing changes from:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1424084444ra/13714080.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>... to:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1452814431ra/17747633.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>All that in a matter of a hundred pages.<br><br>For all of you people who have not read these books, I need to tell you one thing: <b>This damned series has every freaking thing you can think about, even horror.</b><br><br>Yes, my friends, there's horror of the kind that makes you stare at the book with eyes very wide, hands very cold, and ragged breathing. It wasn't present before. <i>Harry Potter</i> wasn't scary, but the final chapters of this book were oh, so dark and unsettling. I know that's how they'll be in the rest of the series, yet it doesn't make my surprise smaller.<br><br>You're probably tired of me saying this, but I must again say how changed the characters are from how they were three books ago. Still in their early teen years, but more mature.<br><br>I read this book for the first time more than four years ago, and of tge seven books, this is the one I remembered the most vividly before rereading. That led me to the conclusion I wrote at the beginning of this review: <b>This is the best book in the series.</b><br><br>Actually, I am mistaken. <b>This is not the best book in the series.</b> They grow better the more you read - the complexity and darkness is greater with each book - but for some reason, <i>Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</i> stuck in my memory better than the others had and became my favourite of the series. Perhaps it was the Tournament and the tasks, or I don't know, but it's clear one thing: <b>This is the book I love the most in the series.</b><br><br>Now, no more ramblings from me. I'm off to reread for the first and definitely not last time the fifth book of this magical series.</span>  <a data-text-id="5815684212622852246" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review854590711">  <td itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/49538742" />    <a title="Liza Martin" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/885654-liza-martin"><img alt="Liza Martin" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1206986990p2/885654.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/49538742?book_show_action=false">Mar 25, 2009</a>      <a title="Liza Martin" class="user" name="Liza Martin" href="/user/show/885654-liza-martin">Liza Martin</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer49538742" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3873103064397871874">So after suffering through the first three books of this series, I vowed never to carry on and finish it. That is, until I was at a party and two of my friends gave the Harry Potter saga such a ringing endorsement that I was convinced I was missing out. I picked up the fourth book and was determined to read it, to reconsider my stance on the series.<br /><br />I quickly got through 200 pages, but it was then that I came to the same crisis I always do when reading a Harry Potter book: Do I really want to go</span>  <span id="freeText3873103064397871874" style="display:none">So after suffering through the first three books of this series, I vowed never to carry on and finish it. That is, until I was at a party and two of my friends gave the Harry Potter saga such a ringing endorsement that I was convinced I was missing out. I picked up the fourth book and was determined to read it, to reconsider my stance on the series.<br /><br />I quickly got through 200 pages, but it was then that I came to the same crisis I always do when reading a Harry Potter book: Do I really want to go on?<br /><br />And as always, the answer was no. So in keeping with my MO that "Life is too short to read books you're not interested in," I put it down and have no regrets.<br /><br />Sorry, Harry and the gang, I just have no interest in you or your adventures. I guess I never really "got" this phenomenon, and that's OK with me. There are better books out there.</span>  <a data-text-id="3873103064397871874" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div href="http://52bookminimum.blogspot.com/" rel="nofollow">http://52bookminimum.blogspot.com/</a><br><br>This was the turning point. Where the books ceased to be books and instead became a lifestyle. Where not only did I laugh, but also cried my eyes out. Where the Hogwarts students became MY friends. MY family. This was when I knew there was no going back and I was committed to the end.<br><br>"It matters not what someone is born, but what they grow to be."<br><br><a href="http://imgur.com/JnMPyAN" rel="nofollow"> <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1386871737i/7468496._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a><br><br>(And The Doctor was in the <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1721287399" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1721287399" />    <a title="Rikke" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4327582-rikke"><img alt="Rikke" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467464893p2/4327582.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1721287399?book_show_action=false">Sep 19, 2016</a>      <a title="Rikke" class="user" name="Rikke" href="/user/show/4327582-rikke">Rikke</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747573630" href="/book/show/862712.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4327582-rikke?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4327582-rikke?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4327582-rikke?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4327582-rikke?shelf=owned-books">owned-books</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1721287399" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17053176543499731340">This is, without a doubt, my favorite Harry Potter novel. It has been my favorite ever since it came out, and it has only improved on rereading. I adore it; I adore the sense of adventure that spills over every page, the expansion of Rowling's magical universe, and the subtle changes that mark the book's passage from children's fiction to more mature young adult.<br /><br />When I was younger I especially adored the book because it introduced me to other magic societies and international schools of wizardry</span>  <span id="freeText17053176543499731340" style="display:none">This is, without a doubt, my favorite Harry Potter novel. It has been my favorite ever since it came out, and it has only improved on rereading. I adore it; I adore the sense of adventure that spills over every page, the expansion of Rowling's magical universe, and the subtle changes that mark the book's passage from children's fiction to more mature young adult.<br /><br />When I was younger I especially adored the book because it introduced me to other magic societies and international schools of wizardry. While Rowling certainly doesn't mention a magic school anywhere near me, she opens up for the possibility. She expands her universe of wonder; she pushes the boundaries, and somehow everything seem closer. More relatable. Magic stops being a distinctly British thing and becomes an international phenomen. Something that could perhaps happen to a girl in Denmark as well. <br /><br />At least that's what I thought then. <br /><br />Rowling's novels are good, but they can at times feel very constricted. There are very few actual environments described; you have the village of Hogsmeade with all its colors and wonders (matching up to Diagon Alley), you have the muggle life with the Dursley family U+2013 always dreary, boring and painful, and you have Hogwarts of course, buzzing with energy, magic sparks and new adventures. At times you have a glimpse of London mixed with a visit at the Weasley's, an occasional tale from the dark prison of Azkaban, but that's really it.<br /><br />Until this book. Not only does it introduce new schools and new environments U+2013 it also takes us to graveyards of horror and Rowling finally mixes her two spheres (the muggle world and the wizarding worlds) in a glorious game of Quidditch. You get to see the union of these two, very different, worlds, and you finally understand how they aren't as separate as one would think; how they depend on each other, gravitate towards each other, and hide each other. Constantly.<br /><br />It's beautiful. And well worth the wait.</span>  <a data-text-id="17053176543499731340" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1721287399">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag"    <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1180068698?book_show_action=false">Apr 07, 2015</a>      <a title="Elena" class="user" name="Elena" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/424390219" />    <a title="Dianne" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2947323-dianne"><img alt="Dianne" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1344907773p2/2947323.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/424390219?book_show_action=false">Mar 27, 2016</a>      <a title="Dianne" class="user" name="Dianne" href="/user/show/2947323-dianne">Dianne</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780439139595" href="/book/show/49130.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2947323-dianne?shelf=best-of-2016">best-of-2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer424390219" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer801390398780719003">OK, I get it. I finally get it. It took me 4 books, but I understand why the release of the Potter books was an EVENT. People dressing up, queuing up, waiting in line overnight to get their hands on the newest Harry Potter book......I am in the Potter groove now. I finished this yesterday and I am sincerely pissed that I don't have the fifth book here and ready to go. However, all is not lost...I do have the first book on my Kindle so I am re-reading that until I can race to the library on</span>  <span id="freeText801390398780719003" style="display:none">OK, I get it. I finally get it. It took me 4 books, but I understand why the release of the Potter books was an EVENT. People dressing up, queuing up, waiting in line overnight to get their hands on the newest Harry Potter book......I am in the Potter groove now. I finished this yesterday and I am sincerely pissed that I don't have the fifth book here and ready to go. However, all is not lost...I do have the first book on my Kindle so I am re-reading that until I can race to the library on Monday and get the next book. Or should I wait a bit and drag out the anticipation? Eeny meeny....<br /><br />"Goblet of Fire" isn't without its problems. It took about 240 pages to really get going (that never-ending world cup Quidditch match, for example) and the end was a bit of a convoluted tangle. BUT....I was hooked once the Beauxbatons and Durmstrang students showed up. Hooked to the point that I refused to get off the couch for my long-standing Saturday night date with my husband and sent him out for take-out.....I had 200 pages to go and NO WAY was I putting this book down. I married a very understanding man - he gets me (bless him!). I finished up in the wee hours and sat up for a while thinking about it.<br /><br />I can already sense the massive book hangover I am going to have when I finish these books. I won't want to leave this world and these characters behind. There's only one first time to read these books and I am going to enjoy the heck out of it! Onward!</span>  <a data-text-id="801390398780719003" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons"> Goblet of Fire has always been my favourite book in the series. It took me awhile to read it, but I loved that.. I loved just spending my time, no rush, with Harry and the Gang.</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_672535513" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/672535513" />    <a title="Thomas" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2018505-thomas"><img alt="Thomas" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1463769552p2/2018505.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/672535513?book_show_action=false">Jul 30, 2013</a>      <a title="Thomas" class="user" name="Thomas" href="/user/show/2018505-thomas">Thomas</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(&#39;reviewTextContainer672535513&#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer672535513" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6500151804258496169"><b>Six reasons why I loved Hermione Granger in <i>Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</i> (spoilers):</b><br /><br />1) On page 290 when Harry tells her to talk to Ron for him and she straight up says "I'm not telling him anything. Tell him yourself. It's the only way to sort this out." Unlike many teens today, Hermione doesn't resort to Twitter or Facebook or Tumblr to resolve her conflicts - she actually uses conversation and compromise! Before anyone mentions the fact that they didn't have Facebook way back when, reme</span>  <span id="freeText6500151804258496169" style="display:none"><b>Six reasons why I loved Hermione Granger in <i>Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire</i> (spoilers):</b><br /><br />1) On page 290 when Harry tells her to talk to Ron for him and she straight up says "I'm not telling him anything. Tell him yourself. It's the only way to sort this out." Unlike many teens today, Hermione doesn't resort to Twitter or Facebook or Tumblr to resolve her conflicts - she actually uses conversation and compromise! Before anyone mentions the fact that they didn't have Facebook way back when, remember that they could've used owls... or something...<br /><br />2) She starts the Society for the Promotion of Elfish Welfare. Not only does she create the club, she believes in her cause even when every other person shuts her down. While I admire her activism, I also love how Rowling incorporated subtler messages about racism. Ron being racist to an extent exemplifies how you don't have to be the KKK to discriminate, and Rowling did a great job portraying positive role models like Lupin and Hagrid as minority groups.<br /><br />3) On page 214 when Hermione tells Moody to stop the Cruciatus Curse, she does so because she senses Neville's discomfort - thus showing that she is sensitive to other people's needs. What a winner.<br /><br />4) Throughout the book when Harry is castigated by his peers Hermione is the only one who sticks by his side. She has no regard for what other people think of her and abides by her own beliefs. I'm glad J.K. Rowling incorporated such a positive role model not only for young girls, but for anyone who reads the series.<br /><br />5) When Ron admits that he would go to the Yule Ball with a girl who were stupid as long as she was pretty, Hermione snaps at him and walks away. She does not give into society's conventions in terms of valuing physical attractiveness as opposed to intelligence. Then, when Ron notes that Hermione is "a girl", she does not devalue herself by appreciating his late realization - she storms off, once again propelled by what she thinks is right.<br /><br />6) At the end of the book when Hermione captures Rita Skeeter she exhibits mercy by promising to eventually set her loose - other characters may have just killed her or allowed her to suffer a much worse fate. Once again, Hermione acts as a great combination of emotion and logic: these days it may seem like young protagonists, especially of the female variety, may only have one of these traits... but, Hermione disproves that.<br /><br />Alas, perhaps I am a hardcore fan of Hermione just because I see so much of myself in her. Overall, I enjoyed reading the fourth installment - Rowling knows how to write a tightly-spun yet scintillating plot. While she overuses adverbs sometimes and has a tendency to reveal everything at the end of the book through heaps of dialogue (this was the case in the previous books too), I stayed up until 2 AM just to speed through the last 150 pages of this book. Looking forward to reading the last three, and apparently much darker, books in this series.</span>  <a data-text-id="6500151804258496169" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review672535513">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link672535513" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=32&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=672535513&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_672535513" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 672535513, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">22  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_889769476" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/889769476" />    <a title="Danae" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/27695727-danae"><img alt="Danae" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1389772365p2/27695727.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/889769476?book_show_action=false">Jun 08, 2015</a>      <a title="Danae" class="user" name="Danae" href="/user/show/27695727-danae">Danae</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780545582957" href="/book/show/17347382-harry-potter-and-the-goblet-of-fire">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer889769476" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4344274348950410998">I'm going to keep up my non-reviews that I did for the past three books which have been gifs from that particular movie. Because let's face it, there's no way anything I say can do these books justice. However, the pic I chose for this review doesn't have much to do with the series, and everything to do with the fact that I forgot David Tennant was in the movie.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1433788377i/15142793.jpg" width="475" height="285" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review889769476">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link889769476" title="Flag this review as inappropriate."  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_663635431" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/663635431" />    <a title="Chelsea (chelseadolling reads)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/16219087-chelsea-chelseadolling-reads"><img alt="Chelsea (chelseadolling reads)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1470722711p2/16219087.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/663635431?book_show_action=false">Jun 01, 2016</a>      <a title="Chelsea (chelseadolling reads)" class="user" name="Chelsea (chelseadolling reads)" href="/user/show/16219087-chelsea-chelseadolling-reads">Chelsea (chelseadolling reads)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/16219087-chelsea-chelseadolling-reads?shelf=own">own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/16219087-chelsea-chelseadolling-reads?shelf=books-ive-reread">books-ive-reread</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer663635431" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2828924990804575392">I'm feeling so many feelings right now. WHY DOES THIS SERIES HURT SO MUCH</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review663635431">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link663635431" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=663635431&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/6.Harry_Potter_and_the_Goblet_of_Fire">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_663635431'><a id="like_count_review_663635431" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/663635431?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">32 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_663635431" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_663635431" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=32&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=663635431&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_663635431" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 663635431, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">comment</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/663635431?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_663635431' style='display: none;'></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_663635431' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 663635431, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_9681454" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/9681454" />    <a title="Mariel" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/647547-mariel"><img alt="Mariel" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1451321467p2/647547.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/9681454?book_show_action=false">Feb 25, 2012</a>      <a title="Mariel" class="user" name="Mariel" href="/user/show/647547-mariel">Mariel</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">flobberworms give bad bite</span></div>          <div>    <span class="greyText">Recommended to Mariel by: </span>      Aragog never killed no one never  </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer9681454" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12041978669018471866">I'm a Harry Potter fan. A rather hardcore one, back in the day. The Harry fans at the big meetup of 2007 (last book) ditched me for not being cool enough. Shows what they know.<br /><br />I don't know if anyone on goodreads followed the intense Harry Potter fanbase core in the good old days. I wasn't on goodreads until after the last book came out. Goblet of Fire was the last Harry Potter book before all of the bitching naysayers. It was never as much fun after that, either to discuss theories or pick apart</span>  <span id="freeText12041978669018471866" style="display:none">I'm a Harry Potter fan. A rather hardcore one, back in the day. The Harry fans at the big meetup of 2007 (last book) ditched me for not being cool enough. Shows what they know.<br /><br />I don't know if anyone on goodreads followed the intense Harry Potter fanbase core in the good old days. I wasn't on goodreads until after the last book came out. Goblet of Fire was the last Harry Potter book before all of the bitching naysayers. It was never as much fun after that, either to discuss theories or pick apart clues. It was also the book that started the "I hate Ron!" club (the Draco Malfoy is a conflicted hero idea started around the Chamber of Secrets film. Hey, I could be a Harry Potter scholar). It was pretty much like looking up any movie on the imdb or a tv show on Television Without Pity. No one hates something more than an obsessive fan, right? Fanfic writers who actually preferred their interpretations more than the original source (crazy!). The fanbase could be deterimental to nuturing ones own "ohmigod I'm going to die without the next book" that I so desperately needed. Harry Potter was my "something to look forward to". I haven't found anything else to take its place. I've not tried to hang around the fringes of a big fan base again, either. (My random goodreads tastes probably don't count. I have no idea what the big thing is. I liked The Hunger Games for the cozy district twelve parts and didn't give a rationed fig for love triangles or political outcome. I'm a loner bookworm freak!) Almost as bad were all of the people who felt some pressing need to inform me that they were too cool to even try to read Harry Potter, as if it made one bit of difference to me. [I suspect that I was expected to backtrack. You know, the way a person will immediately downplay how much they liked or disliked something based on what someone else says about it.] I was going to read it with or without them. They were not beating me by being too cool for school (especially if that school is Hogwarts!). Why were they too cool for Harry after Goblet of Fire? The fans, I mean.<br /><br />I don't remember an awful lot about plot points (I'm older now and my memory wasn't that good to begin with). There is some overlap between books, for sure. I do remember savoring the details and not because it would help me figure out was going to happen. I WANTED surprises. Harry disliking Ron for the bit of skin showing between his ankles and his pajama ends? That would totally have swayed me to be unwilling to hear an apology and nurse the annoyance another few days. I loved it when the whole school hated Harry (which is about all of the time). I loved how he didn't study and had to work up to the last minute nerve for everything. Those kinds of details made it for me. I remember the wait between the books and being excited to find out what Neville was up to over the summer (long live Neville Longbottom!). But no, the base was miffed 'cause they didn't get another Sirius Black who owned the motorbike that Hagrid used to escort Harry to Privet Drive appearing in Prisoner of Azkaban. If that's what you wanted the appeal of Harry Potter would be dead in the water with the giant squid after the last book. That's not me!<br /><br />Oh yeah, so it was a huge turning point in the series. Voldemort rises again, the romance shit (Rowling's one big flaw, in my mind). They got longer and less tightly edited (we fans were greedy for closer release dates. They had no one but themselves to blame!). Maybe some details got piled on (I can't remember which book had the useless James Potter quidditch info. Half-blood?). <br /><br />I think it was the Ron thing, anyway. D'oh. It has to be that. Maybe it was like season three of Buffy when Buffy goes to L.A. in the first episode and they still cut back to Sunnydale to show how the Scooby gang are faring without her. The new factors of the war is out there situation was like cutting into the Scooby dynamic. It's painful to go your own way and be all alone. It was like reaching the end half way through. Harry has to grow up, he has to defeat Lord Voldything and leave Hogwarts. And that's a sad feeling 'cause it means that I also have to leave Hogwarts. The bitching had to be about change. It still worked, it just worked in a different way. Change isn't popular.<br /><br />There are faults in the series but I loved what I loved so much that I didn't care. I just want to be in Hogwarts. I could tease about what I didn't like and still loved what I loved. How to be a Harry Potter fan in the style of Mariel 101. I'm sure I'll be rewarded with my Hogwarts letter any day now.<br /><br />D'oh! Of course! S.P.E.W. I remember now. (Society for Promotion of Elvish Welfare for the non-nerds. Oh wait, those people will not be reading this.) All the dumbfucks argued that the house elves wanted to be enslaved and that the point of the series was that Hermione was representing America rushing in to save oppressed civilizations when they shouldn't have been involved. (Dudes, they were probably the ones they needed saving from.) Uggggggh. So children should have always slaved away in factories because that was their only wages? Because they saw the film Newsies and Christian Bale looked like he was having a lot of fun? Killing Mudbloods is bad ("Sure, I don't want to kill kids but wars in the middle east are still a great idea!") but reading about equality for all is less interesting if it changes the bottom line? I probably started resenting the fanbase a whole lot right around that time. Rowling could have made the point less hammer-head like (via Hermione). The films succeeded in that quite well. But still! It is like being in the wizarding world itself to have read that kind of crap. Bigots everywhere. Poor Dobby! Sobs. (Winky was fucking annoying, though.)<br /><br />I also didn't mention the "Harry is a Death Eater" people. I wonder where they are right now. Probably in a dark corner of the internet somewhere, writing about the "truth" of the Harry Potter series. Grrrrrrrrrrrr. Harry is all that is good and pure in this world!<br /><br />P.s. I always skipped Quidditch scenes. The Triwizard scenes were kinda Quidditch-y to me. For that reason Goblet is my least favorite of the series. And I hated reading about Ron not liking Harry. But still! I remember when I got Goblet of Fire. I had to go to work and stop reading it. I didn't think about anything else but what was going to happen next in this book. Every other day was I numb with wanting to be anywhere else. That day I was happy to be in my own head. Goblet of Fire is a great book by my own definition because of that.</span>  <a data-text-id="12041978669018471866" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review9681454">  <td colspan="2">    <div
